title: Monday, 4th June, 2018
bodyHTML:
#REF! Alfa financial software please. Everyone loves a Friday 14:18 Trading Statement. Co-inciding with end of lock up as well I think
11:05 am
BE11:05am

Good morning, and welcome to another corner of FT dot com where you can tell us that you hate us.

Blank canvas good morning everyone
Soundbuy Morning
vonB Morning all

There are already 414 or so expressions of hatred over here: https://www.ft.com...-ad91-e01af256df68

Swedish Chef Don’t hate anybody here but it seems my dislike of Patterson is going institutional

This one's got 20-odd at pixel time: https://ftalphavil...le-dream-at-Tesla/

Excel Developer Morning, why start with a picture when you can start with a sketch? Here's Peter Cook at his finest satirising Jeremy Thorpe case Justice Cantley https://www.youtube.com/embed/RZdaQQBZ3as?start=3464&end=3490 re last night's telly.

And that's before we go into the classics like https://ftalphavil...ide-to-the-future/

"No one likes us, we don't care", I think the Millwall song went.

patatbat any idea why UK utils strong today?? Someone got a sector note out?
BE11:09am

Except we kinda do. I know from experience that it's pretty disheartening to see the comment box light up with folk calling you all sorts because you've written something that doesn't match their pre-established view. Phrases like "hit job" and "clickbait" and stuff like that can be rather wearing to read.

Soundbuy Smurfit looking weak - as you'd expect given deadline and........zilch....
11:10 am
BE11:10am

Anyway, do follow those links above. And if they make you angry, feel free to come back and shout at me.

#REF! Re the Tesla stuff, there's been years of people buying the hype, I support AV trying to fight back by pointing out missed promises. But Tesla has big set of 'followers' who will jump to its defence

Smurfit Kappa Group PLC (SKG:LSE): Last: 2,930, down 172 (-5.54%), High: 3,162, Low: 2,916, Volume: 970.22k

Shrink Morning!

Sources familiar with the matter said that neither side has engaged with the other since the Irish Takeover Panel moved in the middle of last month to set a deadline of 7am on June 6th for IP to announce a binding offer for Smurfit Kappa or face a 12-month ban from being able to mount another approach.

Swedish Chef @pat Yep. Wondering why my water cos up too.
11:12 am
BE11:12am

It also cites the Wells note from Friday putting the chances of a deal at one-in-five.

Soundbuy Mondi getting a mention.....https://www.thetimes.co.uk/edition/business/crunch-time-for-smurfit-kappa-bid-fight-9lhgwpjv0
BE11:14am

That note was citing Smurfit investors, interestingly. It also argued that IP investors would prefer buybacks to M&A.

BE11:14am

Also, as noted, Ben H's wrap of the situation in the Sunday Times. https://www.thetim...-909e-3e8bc48c88c9

vonB Meanwhile Smith DS just gets on with it
11:15 am
BE11:15am

He reports I think for the second time that Mondi is working with UBS and Rothschild to kick around options.

ActiveValue1 Morning, please keep the Tesla/Jordan/Plus 500 balance coming. There is no point only reading the bull case, we do not need yet another echo chamber!
BE11:16am

With the caveat that a Mondi-Smurfit merger is far from the only option here.

Tom Dalgleish Last time I looked CMC wouldnt short Tesla
Blackbag99 I'll challenge you for your conventional views BE. Far to much now and not enough future. Ignore time construct.
BE11:17am

And since we're here, the Irish Independent on Sunday has what looks like a fairly speculative piece about the possibility that International Paper raises to €40 level and that talks begin.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

(@Blackbag99: I'll try to be less conventional in future, sorry.)

BE11:18am

Anyway, June 6 deadline. So, really, may as well wait.

undefined
11:18 am
BE11:18am

Meanwhile, DS Smith.

Tom Dalgleish ......but a short on lithium may be as good
Badger I'm not sure i would want a car that, in this brave new future that Tesla fans imagine, relies so heavily on technology working uninterrupted and being utterly hack proof.
BE11:19am

... which refuses to autoprice. Up 3.1% live.

wayneJ @Tom - short lithium? Would be interested in views on EV adoption generally
cleverhedge @ #REF ... Alfa.ln .. what a Friday!
BE11:20am

Buying Europac for €1.9bn, which is nearly no premium on Friday's close oddly.

Blackbag99 I don't own Smurfit, but as a small shareholder not enough cash
11:20 am
BE11:20am

£1bn rights issue, rest in debt.

Blackbag99 DS Smith, frustrated by refusal to autoprice
cleverhedge @ #REF Berenberg Target cut to 170p from 600p
BE11:21am

Europac (full name Papeles y Cartones de Europa) is family controlled and this all looks very friendly.

Tom Dalgleish Wayne, slower and with speed humps. Notably TSLA and the Li supply contracted to it
BE11:21am

Only needs 50% +1 acceptances, already has 59%.

#REF! @cleverhedge yeah well 'mission critical software' message somewhat undermined if customers seem ambivalent on when it is installed
Shinshin Tesla's missed the boat. Even if they could fix all their problems magically overnight, Mercedes, BMW, Nissault and Toyota have caught up on th tech, and already have the production processes and scale custome distribution - much the harder parts - in place.
11:22 am
BE11:22am

This is slightly outside DS Smith's wheelhouse, which we'll get to in a moment. First, though, the numbers. Here's Goldman to summarise, even though it's on the deal.

Blackbag99 No shortage of lithium, just depends on the price you are willing to pay. Just as there is no shortage of oil
wayneJ @tom - very fair. Had a TSLA sales call at the weekend. For a company whose cars are flying off the shelves odd that they regularly ring me.
Excel Developer From Mance: "(JP) often uses the longest word possible" , yeah I've noticed that.
BE11:23am

The implied EV of the transaction is €1,904mn (£1,659mn),
according to the press release, which implies a 10.8x EV/EBITDA LTM pre-synergies expected by the company, and 8.4x EV/EBITDA LTM including the full run rate of pre-tax cost synergies. The cost synergies identified by DS Smith are €50mn (c.£44mn) equal to c.5.6% of Europac’s sales LTM.
DS Smith has received undertakings to accept the acquisition from a total of 58.97% of the entire share capital of Europac which is binding under all circumstances. The acquisition will be financed by a rights issue of c.£1,000mn (c.€1,148mn) net of expenses which has been fully underwritten and a new committed debt facility of £650mn (c.€746mn). DS Smith expects to publish a prospectus and launch the rights issue at the time of the announcement of its full-year results in June. The deal is subject to regulatory approvals as well as approval by DS Smith shareholders; DS Smith expects the deal to close in 4Q2018.

Tom Dalgleish That battery powered passenger aircraft in Alphaville case in point. Batteries are heavy
BE11:23am

After completion of the acquisition, DS Smith expect to have ND/EBITDA of less than 2.5x by the end of the current financial year with a clear deleveraging path to below DS Smith’s net debt to EBITDA medium-term target of 2.0x. DS Smith expects the deal to be accretive to EPS in the first full financial year of ownership and ROIC (pre-tax) to exceed WACC.
Europac produced c.940kt of container board and c.360kt of corrugated packaging in 2017 and, if approved, this acquisition would lower DS Smith’s net short position of container board.

Shinshin That's not to knock Musk, who moved the Overton window on EV and in doing so singelhandedly changed an industrial sector and global air quality
11:23 am
BE11:23am

And Caz, with a bit more comment.

BE11:24am

In our opinion, the acquisition will (1) build scale in the growing Iberian packaging market; (2) strengthen DS Smith’s paper supply chain; (3) provide opportunities to realise synergies and ongoing integration benefits; and (4) offer scope to improve the underlying performance of Europac’s packaging operations.

Shinshin I'd be more than happy if my gravestone read "reduced air particulates and saved lives"
BE11:24am

"But what does this mean for kraftliner?" I hear you ask.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

I mean, I can see you going on about Elon Musk on the right yet again, but I assume you're also quietly asking "but what does this mean for kraftliner?"

BE11:25am

Here's Goodbody.

GBKrona Which is more structurally advantaged- Mondi or DS Smith?
BE11:25am

Europac produces 940,000 tonnes of kraftliner and re-cycled papers and 360,000 tonnes of corrugated packaging. It is of note that this is DS Smith’s first move into kraftliner in Europe. While somewhat at odds with the groups long standing strategy to only produce recycled containerboard, we believe that this strengthens the groups position. We estimate that the acquisition will add 22% to FY19 forecasts on a proforma basis including synergies with upside given momentum in kraftliner pricing and the readily achievable synergy number. Net debt /EBITDA will increase to 2.4x on the same basis.

11:25 am
undefined

BE11:26am

Alfa Financial mentioned on the right, following Friday's rather exciting trading update.

Blackbag99 Telsa will survive if it survives the media onslaught. We need batteries that last 500 miles, which is BS, most people don't do more than 50 miles a day. And 40% of the worlds population park their car on their drive. Massive markets that doesn't require big batteries.
BE11:26am

Just over a year after this thing floated.

Bryan Good morning guys, I read an information about a possible offer from Giencore to buy Bunged. They already talked about it last year but it seems that the talks are resumed. Does anyone know anything about it?
11:27 am
BE11:28am

All the press around it at the time was, "sure, is has very few actual customers. Like, fewer than a dozen. But to those fewer than a dozen customers Alfa's absolutely crucial."

BE11:28am

Seems ....... not.

BE11:28am

A top-three customer has decided that it needs to get its own stuff sorted before pushing the button on a project.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

And the dropthrough to earnings from that revenue shortfall is .... well, it's much as the risk factors in last year's flotation flagged ... but oh well.

Alfa Financial Software Holdings PLC (ALFA:LSE): Last: 157.80, down 27.2 (-14.70%), High: 193.88, Low: 146.80, Volume: 5.48m
BE11:30am

Berenberg are no longer buyers.

#REF! There's three problem clients in the trading statement. If they have 12 customers.. 1/4 of customers are problematic....
11:30 am
BE11:30am

While this news is highly unexpected, revenue phasing has always been a key risk in Alfa’s business model. Unfortunately, it seems as though the company is experiencing an almost worst-case scenario in terms of the timing and magnitude of lost revenue. With a c95% drop-through margin on this revenue, we reduce our 2018 EBIT estimate by c50%. With a higher degree of conservatism by management on the 2019 pipeline also, we believe this magnitude of earnings cut will take place in outer years also. With considerable uncertainty both in the short and medium term, we downgrade our rating to Hold and reduce our price target to 170p.

Pharma @Blackbag if you are going to spend £30k+ on a car, no point if it doesn't meet the edge case, which for most people is occasional 2-300 mile trips. Having to stop for an hour on the way to charge, and cadge electricity when you get where you are going is not going to be seen as progress.
BE11:31am

We believe this issue stems from an unresolved data issue in their customers’ legacy systems which must be resolved before Alfa can progress. Although management believe this contract can be restarted in 2019, any further delays would constitute a risk. Alfa also highlighted delays in other customer starts, due to timing and/or increased project scope.

BE11:31am

These delays will have a significant impact on 2018 numbers, with the company revising full revenue guidance to £71m-75m (compared to consensus estimates of £92m beforehand). With greater conservatism by management on its 2019 pipeline, plus the secondary effect of lost revenue in ODS and maintenance, we cut our 2019 revenues by 30% also. With Alfa’s largest cost being their staff, which they are unlikely to cut, we believe the company will have to weather substantially lower margins for a period of time as a result of lower staff utilisation.

Mouselet good morning everybody
BornCynic Morning - BE I know of a Guardian journalist who describes the comments section as "a bottomless cesspit".
11:33 am
BE11:33am

And Barclays.

Blackbag99 most people is occasional 2-300 mile trips. Most people don't drive non stop. You will find the electrical charging point closest to services. lol
Mouselet Jay Rayner seems to cope, but professional-chef-level thick skin is not universal and should not be required of all journalists
BE11:33am

These are an unusual cluster of delays and do not impact the leading standing of the group. However, the strong prospects and culture mean the company has limited scope to reduce costs, and therefore utilization and therefore profitability will likely be structurally lower for the foreseeable future.

BornCynic The wisdom of crowds does sometimes appear to be "I hate you and your opinions".
Tom Dalgleish Tesla's manufacturing costs seem intractably high for a simple concept
Mouselet Hiring a different car for the long trips doesn't seem that awful a plan, though it does make you wonder why you own a car at all

We reduce our revenue est. for ‘18/’19/’20 by 28%/36%31%,
implying just 5% growth in ’19 due to uncertainty and 20% in 2020 (normalization of growth). Given the high fixed cost and the decision to continue graduate recruitment, the revenue shortfall will completely fall through in ’18 and see some offset in ‘19’20 due to savings. As a result, our EPS are reduced by 60%/55%%/49% for 2018-20.

We reduce our price target to 205p based on 25x FY20 PE – we suspect that the size of the warning and the questions around the business model mean the stock could substantially trade below fair value.

BE11:34am

Yep.

BE11:38am

On consolidation, Soren Schroder said .....

Pharma @Blackbag99 perhaps when I get to my parents age I will agree, but at the moment the idea of stopping at a service station for 45min just to ensure I can get where I'm going is an anathema.Plus, when everyone has an EV, the spaces will be exactly where they currently are for regular cars, and occupied for much longer on average too.
BE11:38am

We've been pretty open about the fact that there are certainly parts of -- part of the Agribusiness world where you have pockets of excess capacity and inefficiencies, where combining forces would make sense. I believe it is mostly regional. It's -- I can point to that easier than I can something big. But grain handling in the U.S., maybe crush in South America, crush in China will be examples of that. And so where that's the case, we've been very active forming partnerships with local or global companies, and we have many examples of that. I think that's -- that is a good way to accomplish consolidation, where you end up either managing joint capacity or utilizing particular assets better in joint than on your own. And so our approach to consolidation from that perspective will continue to be what we can control, which is more the regional approach.

11:38 am
BE11:39am

Which doesn't tell us an awful lot really. As you'd expect. Anyway, it's a habitual rumour that we note rather than endorse.

undefined

Q1s due July 19, ahead of which there's a certain amount of speculation. I think the Independent had something a bit gloomy.

11:43 am

Also gloomy, here's MOST's preview.

BE11:44am

Group Revenue +14% £796m, Adjusted EBITDA £(6)m. The company has already said Group revenues are expected to be c.£796m in FY18 with adj. EBITDA of £(6)m. Current company provided consensus is for £795m revenue and £(4)m of adjusted EBITDA. By division, we expect UK Revenue to have grown 8% to £680m with an adjusted EBITDA of £22m, while we expect Europe revenue of £116m, +63% reported growth with an EBITDA of £(27)m.

Blank canvas underwhelming news at Virgin Money?
kim @ED - when did they poll for investor sentiment? It's been a bit up and down recently? :)
BE11:44am

The focus will be on outlook for FY19. In the 3Q trading update, the company reiterated its cautious stance on near-term market conditions owing to the uncertain macro outlook in the UK. We note that Dixons Carphone, the largest electrical retailer in the UK profit warned this week, partially due to a shrinking market for electrical goods. We expect AO World to deliver 11% revenue growth to £882m with an adjusted EBITDA of £2m for FY19. Current consensus expects £883m, 11% yoy with an adjusted EBITDA of £5m

Finlay thanks
11:44 am
BE11:44am

We are Underweight AO World. While growth in Europe has exceeded expectations, the UK business still faces competitive and macro headwinds. Given the UK is the only part of the business close to profitability, any significant slowdown could affect AO's ability to invest in Europe. The shares have had a strong run on the back off outperformance of other UK internet names (ZPG, Ocado) and are trading at 0.8x 2019e EV/Sales but we still think a discount to European eCommerce peers (1.6x 2019 EV/Sales) with larger TAMs, stronger revenue profiles and market positions is justified.

undefined

BE11:52am

Oh, and I guess we should probably mention .....

BE11:52am

Italy’s UniCredit is plotting to merge with French rival Société Générale in a bold move that would see two of Europe’s big banks join forces, leading the way for an expected round of banking mergers on the continent.

Jean-Pierre Mustier, the French chief executive of UniCredit, has been pioneering the idea for several months, according to people close to the situation. They said no formal approach has been made but SocGen directors have also been studying the possibility of a combination.

11:52 am
BE11:52am

https://www.ft.com...-b6eb-4acfcfb08c11

BE11:53am

Coming so soon after the BarChart story, you could almost call this a trend.

BE11:54am

( https://www.ft.com...-9334-2218e7146b04 )

11:55 am
BE11:55am

Kepler saying SocGen's now in play ......

BE11:55am

Both banks are now trading at an equivalent market cap (EUR32bn for UC vs. EUR30bn for SocGen) and both can claim for a “merger of equals”. However, we should not be lured into thinking that SocGen has the upper hand in this. In his eighteen month into the job, Mustier has helped Unicredit’s share price significantly outperform SocGen’s (see Table 1 overleaf) and the French bank’s earnings report have been disappointing since Q1 2017, making us believe that SocGen is now ready to give up its independence after two attempts to take it over failed (in 1988 and in 1999-2000). Société Générale is now at play, in our view, and this warrants an upgrade of our rating from Hold to Buy.

BE11:56am

Would SocGen-StanChart make sense? I imagine not. Not even slightly.

JuB fwiw I liked the Jordan Peterson writeup ... interesting guy
11:57 am
BE11:57am

Charts on UniSoc from Citi:

BE11:58am

BE11:59am

And a bit of "probably won't happen" comment from Morgan Stanley.

11:59 am
BE11:59am

Although business rationale exists we think chances of a near term deal look low given execution risks and regulatory scrutiny/obstacles to such a large potential merger. It seems a deal, if it were to happen, would be unlikely until 2019/2020 at the earliest given UCG's commitment to restructuring targets and given the state of regulations which make cross-border transactions tough. In terms of rationale in favour: (i) this potential combination has been considered in the past (pre-crisis) and Unicredit CEO Jean Pierre Mustier has history with Soc Gen as he was its head of Corporate and Investment bank. (ii) Some industrial logic - given some business overlap in CEE for example (Czech, Romania, Russia among others) could drive synergies, core Pan European focus (largest markets France, Italy, Germany). The banks are similar sized from a balance sheet (SG ~€1.3trn, UCG ~€0.8trn assets) and market cap standpoint (Soc Gen €30bn, UCG €33bn). Assuming 10% cost cutting on a combined cost base of €29bn, potential synergies could be material on a combined MSe 2020e Underlying PBT of ~€15.5bn. In truth, this looks to be long dated given: (i) UCG is still mid-way through a 2019 business plan including non-core run-down, (ii) Soc Gen has still to settle litigation (LIA and LIBOR settlements announced today) but OFAC could still take some time, (iii) moreover cross-border M&A still remains tough (possible G-SIFI implications, execution risks) and the short term volatility in Italian politics is unlikely to help.

undefined
